awd_titl_txt: Uncovering the molecular mechanism of paramutation, a classic example of non-Mendelian inheritance in maize
awd_abstract_narration:
This project investigates a biological mechanism, called paramutation, which is responsible for turning selected genes "on" and "off" in highly predictable ways and for passing these "on" and "off" states to future generations.  Similar to the well-known process of mutation, paramutation generates heritable biological variation that impacts evolutionary success. Unlike mutations, however, paramutations occur without changes to the DNA code. The project thus addresses an exception to an established rule of modern genetics by asking how regulatory information is altered and transmitted to offspring in the absence of DNA changes. The work will be carried out in corn, the preeminent model for studying the paramutation mechanism because the "on" and "off" states of genes responsible for plant color are visually tracked, controlled matings are simple to perform, and detailed multigenerational pedigrees can be generated and evaluated. A working model for paramutation has been proposed based on research and this project tests specific aspects of that model. The project will also identify novel molecules and chromosome structures responsible for the "on" and "off" switching during paramutations. Because paramutation occurs in both plants and animals, the results of this research could have broad biological impact, ranging from increased understanding of reproductive biology and genetics to development of novel strategies for improving agriculture or animal health. Educational materials such as colorful corn ears will be generated and made available through existing outreach programs for teaching both basic and advanced genetic concepts in the classroom. The activities integrate the training of young scientists at undergraduate and graduate levels as well as provide research experiences for high school students. 

Paramutation describes a behavior in which specific trans-homolog interactions result in meiotically-heritable regulatory alterations. This behavior is potentially mediated by small RNAs but the mechanism remain largely unknown. A model system was developed using plant and flower color to define the molecular mechanism of paramutation occurring in maize. Expression of the purple plant1 gene is monitored with visible pigments. A strong purple state of the Pl1-Rhoades (Pl1-Rh) allele can change to weaker expression states referred to as Pl'. When purple types (Pl/Pl) are mated with weakly pigmented plants (Pl/Pl'), only weakly pigmented progeny - from which only Pl' states are sexually transmitted - are obtained; this is a classic example of paramutation. Forward genetics identifies important cis-acting regions and fifteen loci whose functions are required to maintain repression (rmr) of Pl' states. Prior projects helped identify five RMR proteins acting in a presumed small RNA-directed DNA methylation pathway and led to the discovery of a co-transcriptional repression mechanism operating to maintain meiotically-heritable regulatory states established by paramutation. This project builds on this emerging mechanistic understanding by combining forward genetics, molecular profiling, and mutant analyses to specifically 1) test working models of the paramutation mechanism by profiling transcription, small RNA levels, and cytosine methylation patterns during paramutation events, 2) functionally define cis-acting sequences responsible for paramutation behaviors through structural characterizations of mutant Pl1-Rh alleles, and 3) discover additional molecular components governing paramutations through positional-based cloning of additional rmr loci. Training and outreach opportunities are integrated in these efforts to provide a greater understanding of fundamental eukaryotic genetics and genome biology.

This project is jointly funded by the Genetics Mechanisms Cluster in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences and the Plant Genome Research Program in the Division of Integrative Organismal Systems.

por.por_cntn:
Colorful pigmentation of corn seeds and flowers is a model trait with a well-understood genetic basis. Over 100 years of academic research has identified the nature of these color "factors/genes" and used them as tools to discover and/or validate fundamental biological principles including Mendelian inheritance, chromosome behavior (crossing-over), mutation, gene structure, and transposable elements ("jumping genes"). This project used standard breeding to create a series of corn varieties and their progeny to 1) investigate the molecular mechanism(s) responsible for an unusual inheritance behavior (paramutation) deviating from Mendelian principles, and 2) provide hands-on visual examples of genetic concepts including dominance vs. recessive relationships, independent assortment, genetic linkage, imprinting (parent-of-origin-dependent gene expression) and paramutation. Both elementary and advanced educational cob sets will be available through the Arabidopsis Biological Resource Center "Greening the Classroom" Program (https://abrc.osu.edu/educators/education).

This project investigated a biological mechanism responsible for both turning specific genes "on" and "off" in highly predictable fashions and for passing these on and off states to future generations. Specifically, the team addressed how and why a specific form (allele) of the purple plant1 (pl1) gene - responsible for corn flower pigmentation - becomes inactivated or "silenced" by a process known as paramutation. Similar to mutation, paramutation also generates heritable variation that impacts evolutionary success. Unlike mutations, however, paramutations occur without DNA sequence changes. The project thus studied an exception to an established rule of modern genetics by asking how gene regulatory information is altered and sexually transmitted in the absence of DNA changes. Gene silencing is still a poorly understood behavior often responsible for human cancer progression as well as unstable engineered traits in genetically modified organisms. Thus, a better understanding of the paramutation mechanism promises novel strategies and diagnostics for improving both agriculture and human health.

A team of undergraduate researchers, graduate student trainees, and one postdoctoral associate used a series of pl1 alleles and genetic mutations to ask 1) what chromosome features facilitate paramutation, and 2) what is the responsible cellular machinery? Multiple lines of experimental results support the role of a small (<150 nucleotide) DNA sequence embedded within direct-repeats (5 copies of the same ~2000 nucleotide sequence) as the switchable pl1 allele regulatory element. The "off" state is associated with covalent modifications (methyl group additions) of specific DNA nucleotides (cytosines) in this small sequence while the "on" state is devoid of these. The team also discovered at least four new proteins required to maintain these off states including two types of motors known to reorganize associations between DNA and the nucleosomes upon which it's wrapped, one protein that cuts double-stranded RNA molecules into 24 nucleotide products, and one protein that potentially recruits an enzyme that adds methyl groups to cytosines. Combined with previous peer-reviewed reports, the project findings support the operation of a grass-specific form of RNA-directed DNA methylation at a defined set of repeated DNA sequences as the molecular mechanism responsible for pl1 paramutation. Project results also support the idea that pollen-transmitted small RNA species help maintain pl1 gene silencing.

The project outcomes highlight the future importance of 1) identifying direct repeats in sequenced genomes, 2) understanding how such repeats are recognized and processed by cellular machinery, and 3) discovering the nature of other non-DNA-based sources of heritable information. The peer-reviewed publications, public datasets, biological materials, and scientific training developed by this project facilitate our greater understanding of both Mendelian and non-Mendelian inheritance in student education, chromosome biology, evolution, and applied plant sciences.
